name: Scanner, department, S3120 Max, S3140 Max
description:
This unit process represents the gate-to-gate production of one Kodak Alaris scanner models S3120 Max & S3140 Max, including power supply and cables (mass = 17.5 kg).  The system boundary includes: 1) the transport of raw materials to multiple manufacturing facilities where various subcomponents are produced; 2) the manufacture of subcomponents; 3) the transport of subcomponents to a different manufacturing plant for final assembly; 4) the assembly of subcomponents into a complete scanner; and 5) the transport of generated waste from the manufacturing facilities to a municipal solid waste landfill.  The following processes and life cycle phases fall outside of the system boundary: 1) packaging of the completed scanner; 2) all transport downstream of the assembly plant gate; 3) sale of product; 4) product use phase; and 5) end-of-life phase (including recycling).

The use of this unit process for the analysis of similar devices requires professional judgement based on the degree of similarity.

processDocumentation.timeDescription: Primary data is valid from 2020 - 2022.  Secondary data is valid from 2005 - 2021.
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The manufacture of a department level scanner that uses 2022 technology including information storage and processing and energy savings features.  The manufacture includes the manufacturing of subcomponents at other facilities and assembly at a central location in Guangzhou, China.
processDocumentation.dataCollectionDescription: All primary data were collected from 2019 to 2021.  Secondary data were collected from 2005-2021.
processDocumentation.completenessDescription:
TREATMENT OF MISSING Environmental Data - all known elementary flows are included, so cutoff is <1%
Technosphere flow data - Intermediate flows are cut-off at less than 1% (physical criteria).  Capital equipment used for manufacturing were not included.  
Note that there were no significant emissions to air, soil, or water from the scanner assembly process.  No emissions were measured and estimnates could not be quantified, but were believed to be were well 0.1% of total emissions from the full cradle to gate process, so zero emissions were included.
Mass Balance - The mass of inputs (not including fuels) balances with the scanner output, so there is less than 1% difference.
processDocumentation.dataSelectionDescription: An attempt was made to include data for all inputs.  Primary data were used where available and the most representative secondary data were used where primary data were not available.
processDocumentation.reviewDetails: Internal review.  The Wood (2021) methodology is almost identical to the methodology described in Wood (2012) which is an ISO 14044 compliant, peer-reviewed LCA report of three Kodak scanners (Kodak i2800; i2600; and i2400), which was peer reviewed by Kate Wennebeck of Rochester Institute of Technology's Pollution Prevention Institute.  A third party review of the current LCA by the New York State Pollution Prevention Institute is in progress and results will be included in a later update to this data.
processDocumentation.dataTreatmentDescription:
Primary data were taken from precise engineering specifications specific to this unit process.  These data were then transformed into material and energy flows using the methodology described in Wood (2022) which is due to be released in July, 2022.  The Wood (2022) methodology, which is an ISO 14044 compliant LCA, was independent third party reviewed. 

Secondary data were taken from the ecoinvent 3.2 database (Wernet et al. 2016) and the U.S. Life Cycle Inventory Database (National Renewable Energy Laboratory 2016).  The data were global except where otherwise specified.
processDocumentation.modelingConstantsDescription:
Allocation rules: Materials were based on actual specifications.  Energy and fuels were allocated to products manufactured at the location based on their mass.
Substitution allocation: Substitution by close proxy ( data for similar processes were used for the components)
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
BOUNDARY CONDITIONS
The system boundary includes: 1) the transport of raw materials to multiple manufacturing facilities where various subcomponents are produced; 2) the manufacture of subcomponents; 3) the transport of subcomponents to a different manufacturing plant for final assembly; 4) the assembly of subcomponents into a complete scanner; and 5) the transport of generated waste from the manufacturing facilities to a municipal solid waste landfill.  The following processes and life cycle phases fall outside of the system boundary: 1) packaging of the completed scanner; 2) all transport downstream of the assembly plant gate; 3) sale of product; 4) product use phase; and 5) end-of-life phase (including recycling).  

DATA COLLECTION
For material inputs, data collection was based on scanner specifications provided by the manufacturer.  Other inputs (e.g. energy; waste transport and disposal) were calculated on the basis of quantity of input per kg of scanner produced.

UNCERTAINTY ESTIMATION
Uncertainty was estimated based on engineering judgment.  Material inputs had less uncertainty because they were based off of precise engineering specifications.  Other inputs  (e.g. energy; waste transport and disposal) had more uncertainty.

Summary is available to public.

processDocumentation.intendedApplication: The intended application for this unit process is for "Accounting" purposes as described in Situation C2 from the Institute for Environment and Sustainablility (2011:3).   As such, it describes the gate-to-gate production of one S3120 Max, or S3140 Max desktop scanner "without being interested in any potential consequences on other parts of the economy" (Institute for Environment and Sustainablility 2011:3) and without consideration of potential benefits from recycling the scanner at the end of its useful life.
processDocumentation.projectDescription:
Data and LCA results are reported in Wood (2022) Life Cycle Assessment Summary Report -
Kodak Alaris models S3120 Max, and S3140 Max Scanners - ISO 14044 Protocol
processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Scanners are manufactured in China, but components represent a global supply chain and secondary data is based on best available data from global sources.

sources.name: Wernet et al. (2016) The ecoinvent database version 3 (part I): overview and methodology.
